docs.snippet: David E. Feller, a lawyer and law professor who researched and argued important civil rights and labor cases, including more than a dozen that went to the Supreme Court, died on Monday in Oakland, Calif. He was 86 and lived in Berkeley, Calif.    ...
docs.lead_paragraph: David E. Feller, a lawyer and law professor who researched and argued important civil rights and labor cases, including more than a dozen that went to the Supreme Court, died on Monday in Oakland, Calif. He was 86 and lived in Berkeley, Calif. In the 1950's, Mr. Feller was on a panel of lawyers who advised and assisted Thurgood Marshall, who was then general counsel for the N.A.A.C.P., in preparing legal action against the racial segregation of schools. Mr. Feller was involved in drafting friend-of-the-court briefs in Brown v. Board of Education and other crucial civil rights cases.
docs.abstract: David E Feller, lawyer and law professor who argued important civil rights and labor cases, dies at age 86; photo (M)

headline.main: David E. Feller, 86; Lawyer Who Argued Key Labor Cases

docs.snippet: EVENTS    TRIUMPHANT JOURNEY -- ''In This World,'' a story of two young Afghans who flee to England in a grueling journey that stands for the fate of refugees worldwide, won the top prize, the Golden Bear, Saturday at the Berlin International Film...
docs.lead_paragraph: EVENTS TRIUMPHANT JOURNEY -- ''In This World,'' a story of two young Afghans who flee to England in a grueling journey that stands for the fate of refugees worldwide, won the top prize, the Golden Bear, Saturday at the Berlin International Film Festival. This British film, directed by Michael Winterbottom, chronicles the migrants' trip in semidocumentary style. ''Adaptation,'' starring Nicolas Cage in a double role and directed by Spike Jonze, won the runner-up Silver Bear award. Patrice Chereau was named best director for ''Son Frère,'' a tale of two brothers who renew their relationship when one becomes terminally ill. Nicole Kidman, Meryl Streep and Julianne Moore won joint awards as best actresses for ''The Hours.'' The best-actor award went to Sam Rockwell for ''Confessions of a Dangerous Mind.'' The top prize for artistic contribution went to Li Yang of China, the screenwriter and director of ''Mang Jing'' (''Blind Shaft''), a crime film about two Chinese coal miners. ''Madame Brouette,'' directed by Moussa Sene Absa, won for best film score. ''Goodbye, Lenin!,'' a tragicomedy about German reunification seen from the East German perspective, won the Blue Angel for best European film.
docs.abstract: Arts Briefing column: In This World wins best picture at Berlin International Film Festival; other winners noted; poets and other literary figures will present their views in opposition to war in Iraq in forum at Avery Fisher Hall; organizers will send hundreds of poems to Laura Bush, who recently postponed poetry symposium; upcoming cultural events of interest noted; photos (M)

docs.snippet: Joe Connelly, a television writer and producer who was one of the creators of the family comedy ''Leave It to Beaver,'' died here on Thursday. He was 85.    Mr. Connelly's 8-year-old son, Rick, was the inspiration for Beaver, and his 14-year-old s...
docs.lead_paragraph: Joe Connelly, a television writer and producer who was one of the creators of the family comedy ''Leave It to Beaver,'' died here on Thursday. He was 85. Mr. Connelly's 8-year-old son, Rick, was the inspiration for Beaver, and his 14-year-old son, Jay, was the model for Beaver's older brother, Wally.
docs.abstract: Joe Connelly, television writer and producer who helped create family comedy Leave It to Beaver, dies at age 85 (M)

headline.main: Joe Connelly, 85, a Creator of 'Leave It to Beaver' on Television

docs.snippet: When the Oscar nominations were announced in Beverly Hills, the New York-based mini-studio Miramax came away with 13 nominations for ''Chicago,'' 10 for ''Gangs of New York,'' 6 for ''Frida'' and 1 for ''The Quiet American.'' And ''The Hours,'' wh...
docs.lead_paragraph: When the Oscar nominations were announced in Beverly Hills, the New York-based mini-studio Miramax came away with 13 nominations for ''Chicago,'' 10 for ''Gangs of New York,'' 6 for ''Frida'' and 1 for ''The Quiet American.'' And ''The Hours,'' which Miramax produced in partnership with Paramount Pictures and which is considered the race's front-runner along with ''Chicago,'' had nine nominations. All told, Miramax has 40 Oscar nominations, the most any studio has had since United Artists in 1940. Rick Lyman

docs.snippet: ''SIR!''     I don't respond.     ''Sir! Can I help you?'' The big Jamaican bass voice booms in my ears. I don't have my faculty ID. Turning, I peer at the security guard through sunglasses, and he nods at the sign-in clipboard for visitors. As I ...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''SIR!'' I don't respond. ''Sir! Can I help you?'' The big Jamaican bass voice booms in my ears. I don't have my faculty ID. Turning, I peer at the security guard through sunglasses, and he nods at the sign-in clipboard for visitors. As I write V-a-l-e-n-t-i-n-o, I ask myself, What would anyone who didn't need to be at the Parsons School of Design be doing here? I'd better get a life, I think. Get a real job.
docs.abstract: Fashion designer Josh Patner article on his students at Parsons School of Design, who have eschewed American fashion industry and have helped renew his own interest in fabric, proportion and mood; photo; drawing (M)

headline.main: They Make Me A Designer Again

docs.snippet: IT was 1993, and the producers Craig Zadan and Neil Meron had a mission: bringing Broadway musicals to Hollywood. But Hollywood wasn't exactly begging to be theatricalized.    Finally, their only television contact at the time, who was at CBS, tol...
docs.lead_paragraph: IT was 1993, and the producers Craig Zadan and Neil Meron had a mission: bringing Broadway musicals to Hollywood. But Hollywood wasn't exactly begging to be theatricalized. Finally, their only television contact at the time, who was at CBS, told them that they could do ''Gypsy'' if they could land Bette Midler. So they did. The resulting show earned big ratings and 12 Emmy nominations, and Mr. Meron and Mr. Zadan had found their niche.
docs.abstract: Article traces successful careers of partners Craig Zadan and Neil Meron, who dominate in production of TV musicals; latest show is Music Man for ABC; photos (M)

headline.main: The Music Men, Bringing Broadway to the Screen

docs.snippet: I ONCE spent almost a month exploring a single neighborhood in Paris, the Sixth Arrondissement. I can imagine visits to Napoleon's Paris or medieval Paris or Hemingway's Paris, and visits concentrating on cafes or flea markets. Gastronomic blowout...
docs.lead_paragraph: I ONCE spent almost a month exploring a single neighborhood in Paris, the Sixth Arrondissement. I can imagine visits to Napoleon's Paris or medieval Paris or Hemingway's Paris, and visits concentrating on cafes or flea markets. Gastronomic blowouts, too, of course, and couture shopping sprees, and museum marathons. Last fall, my wife, Betsey, and I devoted the better part of a week to the city's architecture -- not the kind of grand (sometimes grandiose) architecture that typifies the city, like Notre-Dame and the Arc de Triomphe, but modern architecture, the architecture of the last century or so.
docs.abstract: R W Apple Jr travel article on modern architecture in Paris; photos; map (L)

docs.snippet: FEW people would disagree with the forecast that stocks would drop if war started tomorrow in Iraq. But two Stanford economics professors, Eric Zitzewitz and Justin Wolfers, go further, predicting that the market would drop 5 percent.    Academics...
docs.lead_paragraph: FEW people would disagree with the forecast that stocks would drop if war started tomorrow in Iraq. But two Stanford economics professors, Eric Zitzewitz and Justin Wolfers, go further, predicting that the market would drop 5 percent. Academics rarely make precise short-term market predictions. The professors arrived at theirs by using standard econometric analysis and an unusual derivative that trades at www.tradesports.com, based in Dublin. At this Web site, you can bet on whether Duke will win the N.C.A.A. basketball title, whether ''Chicago'' will win the Oscar for best picture or where the Dow Jones industrials will end 2003. According to John Delaney, the site's chief executive, most of its active users are traders from Wall Street or Chicago futures exchanges.
docs.abstract: Mark Hulburt column on prediction by two Stanford economics professors, Eric Zitzewitz and Justin Wolfers, that Standard & Poor's 500 index will drop 5 percent on day war starts in Iraq; notes that they based prediction on futures contract -- traded on Web site in Dublin -- that will pay $10 if Saddam Hussein is not Iraq's president on June 30 and nothing if he still is; contract was last traded at $7.50; graph (M)

headline.main: There's a Futures Contract for Everything (Even Iraq's Fate)

docs.snippet: DEREK BROWN strides into the room, all brisk self-assurance, firm handshake, impeccable tailoring, dossier-laden assistant four paces behind. A prosperous banker, perhaps, or a clever chap in the City.    But this is not London, and while Mr. Brow...
docs.lead_paragraph: DEREK BROWN strides into the room, all brisk self-assurance, firm handshake, impeccable tailoring, dossier-laden assistant four paces behind. A prosperous banker, perhaps, or a clever chap in the City. But this is not London, and while Mr. Brown is unmistakably Anglo-Saxon, as they say here, he is neither banker nor broker. He runs the quintessential French business: publishing the world's most prominent assessment of the best in restaurants and hotels, the Michelin Guides. He is the first non-Frenchman to head Michelin publications in their 103-year history.
docs.abstract: Profile and interview with Derek Brown, Englishman who is first non-Frenchman to head Michelin guides to hotels and restaurants in Michelen publications' 103-year history; photo (M)

headline.main: Michelin's Briton Keeps France's Cuisine Haute

docs.snippet: Stocks Rally as Inspectors Ask for More Time in Iraq  Stocks rallied, sending the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to its biggest gain in almost six weeks, as United Nations weapons inspectors pressed for more time to work in Iraq.    The S.& P. ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks Rally as Inspectors Ask for More Time in Iraq Stocks rallied, sending the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to its biggest gain in almost six weeks, as United Nations weapons inspectors pressed for more time to work in Iraq. The S.& P. 500 rose 17.52 points, or 2.1 percent, to 834.89, its largest gain since Jan. 6. The Dow Jones industrial average added 158.93 points, or 2.1 percent, to 7,908.80. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 32.73 points, or 2.6 percent, to 1,310.17. [Page C4.]
